I got my new HTC Desire HD 3 days ago and last night I sat and designed this tri-pod mount. Added some holes to make it not look too plain and obviously use a little less plastic too. I first printed a 3mm test piece to check for fit over the phone. It has a nice loose fit so you won't need to force the phone in and risk scratching it. I do have SW2010 part file available if someone wants to modify it. [EDIT] I used my Surface Mapping Tool http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7940 and a digital caliper to "map" the contour of the back of the phone. I just did one half and then mirrored the measurements for the other half. So, I can also give you the "map" sketch if you want to design your own stuff.
Print and place with hole over your stock tri-pod attachment's screw. Use a nut on top to hold it down.

title: Mercedes Car Jack Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Jack adapter to lift your car at the factory jack points with a standard hydraulic car jack. It perfectly matches the shape of the onboard car jack in the vehicle tool kit (which also has a plastic head).
I used it for changing my 2006 CL203 from winter to summer tires this spring and it worked w/o any problems, see my last picture during jacking.
It definitely works on all C-class types (W203, S203, CL203) produced 2000-2007. Pretty sure it should be the same for other classes of that time frame. Not sure if they changed the factory car jack points ever since, but it looks like even todays models still have the same.
To all beginners: be careful. Bad prints (little infill, poor layer bonding, weak material, etc.) are a safety risk in this case. You are the producer, you are responsible for safe usage.
Update: added new stl to fix a not-manifold issue.
Print solid! ;-)

author: jsc

description.text: 3D printable battery box for 2 x AA batteries.

Pretty straightforward build.
  • Download the .stl
  • Slice in whatever program you like
  • Print.
  • Drill out the banana plug sockets
  • Add the springs and bar to connect the cells
  • Add the cells and tie wrap in place
  • Play.
    • As a guide for the slicer settings I went for 25% infill and a .4mm layer. Seemed to work well for me. That's it, Enjoy

description.text: This Tripod Adapter plate matches on 22mm diameter Omni antenna and low budget tripod "Esmart Alpha3". I made this for temporary WLAN installations.

printing with antenna side on bottom without support material okay. 0,4mm nozzle, 0,25mm layer height, PLA. Tricky part is ~8mm bridging on top of antenna radius. Use support material if bridging is a problem for your print setup.

comments.text: what tripod you use
comments.author: Ericks

description.text:
A simple device that will reflect the charging status light from the MagSafe 2 adapter on to the top of your computer.  
When I charge my MacBook, the MagSafe adapter usually isn't easily visible, so this allows you to quickly glance at the charging status of your computer.  
White or clear filament would probably work best for this print.  
Printed on a MakerBot Replicator 2 with MakerBot True White filament.
Print at 0.15mm layer height with a raft and support.

author: randythegod

description.text: 1/4" I.D. hose vacuum bagging connector with straight port, no schrader valve, non-shear disk, and o-ring sealed breach. Or you could just call it a "frog". Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:61666 by DariusShekari Used for expoxy vacuum infusion of ABS 3d printed parts. See additional images for the ultra cheap set-up :)

0.3mm, 3 layer, 90% fill for Foot.  
0.2mm, 3 layers, 25% fill for Ring and Nut  
Made with or without rafts, no supports. PLA @ 240 C, feed 100 mm/s.  
Use with -223 O-ring for seal.  
Bag goes between o-ring and ring. Hole in bag should be snug around base of threaded stem of foot before tightening the nut.
Wipe clean before expoxy/resin sets. Drill hole if clogged. Gets better with each use. If used to full cure, throw foot away and print another.

remixed_from.title: Enlarged Rostock Carriage V1.1 for 12mm smooth rod & KB-12-WW bearings

remixed_from.author: Okatake
remixed_from.title: Parametric Shaft Coupling,5mm/6mm converted to a 5mm

title: Enlarged Rostock Carriage V1.2 for 12mm smooth rod

description.text:
Enlarged Rostock Carriage from Jcrocholl modified to:
  • Include a belt tensionning device
  • Take 12x1000mm smooth rods and KB-12-WW Linear Bearings
  • Should clip the bearings (tested)
  • 0.10Â° bearing holder angles to compensate play
  • Changed groove to improve fabricability
  • T2.5 self locking belt mount based on belt_coupler_v6 from Okatake
    • Some slight updates for better printing of the belt coupler

2 out of 3 built at the Artilect FabLab Toulouse on a Prusa with 0.25mm layer height It is necessary to be at least at 0.25mm or lower to get the T2.5 belt grooves correctely  
Thoses were built with 0.1 fill density but it seems a bit to light I would recomend 0.2   
The 0.1Â° angles on the bearings is working well: no play and the carriage is going freely  
The belt tensioner works, it is not prefect yet & for some reason the small bit dose not comes out quite as neat as the biger part

comments.text:
Thanks to the model
But if I wanted to go for smooth bars of the original design from 762x8mm?
What would I change in the code dell'OpenScad?

I have gone 7 years without handles on these cabinets. Today, I got sick of it and printed out my solution.

After painting the cabinets and doors a color I didn't really like after I was done, I vowed to get new paint and repaint them. Some years later I still have that ugly paint and lost all of the hardware for the doors.

The test print is an ulgy orange but I will be printing the a complete set in silver or white. The holes are set for threading in a #8-32 machine screw and are 6.5 mm deep (a little over 1/4"). No extra drilling should be required on the handle. I had 1 inch thick doors so I used 1 1/4" long screws. If anyone likes the style but needs a different size let me know. I could modify these to fit most sizes. I included the Sketchup file as always. -- Photo update:
Shown in white as a pair installed.

How to deal with small tubes for spray cans? Use the tube holder.  
Change the parameters in the .scad-file to fit your needs!

title: Rubber Buttons for Door Opening Remote Control

description.text:
Rubber Buttons for Door Opening Remote Control  
The Remote control at work got run over by a forklift.  
Fortunately it wasn't the Sky+ remote, otherwise we'd not be able to watch Bargain Hunt on BBC or switch to Jeremy Kyle on ITV.  
Sadly, it's the remote control for opening the rear door. Our rear door has a big "No Entry" on it at the moment. Let's open up back there by rebuilding the remote.  
So, first step, design the surviving buttons.  
If you've got a SLA, maybe like the Peachy Printer, maybe you can print these buttons in Maker Juice to give it some fleixbility?  
Of course, I've not got my Peachy (yet) - Hint hint Rylan - I'm eager to get using it for small flexible parts.  
Anyway, these are the "as is" buttons. I may do custom print ones later.  
I've included the native format files so you guys can see the way I've put it together. Basically the Elliptical buttons were the hardest. I can't for the life of me see how to draw ellipses in Creo Elements. To counter this, I created a new part - button - and then I stretched it by 50% on one side, positioned it, rotated it, duplicated it, and then merged the three solids together,  
PRINTABLE VERSION:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:804378
CIRCUIT BOARD FROM INSIDE CONTROLLER:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:805722

Anyway, Enjoy!  
Bath Robotics,  
aka Eur Ing Andy Southern

title: ZMR250 Tilt Gimbal with bigger Standoff's holes

description.text:
Thanks MoRayCH for the original design.
Holes were just too small for standoff (maybe because it's not original ZMR I've got ?).
Here is version with a little bigger holes (6mm instead of 5mm) I've managed to print bumpers with Ninja semi-flex (100% fill) filament in order to absorb frontal shocks Second remix for bumpers, bigger (better protection), and with 5.8mm hole to fit standoff with ninja semi flex filament. You can purchase complet gimbal kit (print (ABS/Ninja Semi flex), servo motor, and Pushrods / music wire 1.2mm) directly from my eBay store:
http://www.ebay.com/sch/yoannwyffels/m.html 05 june 2015
Added "Simplified Panels_attachw_ziptie.stl" file. Source panels are a little bit weak in case of crash. I've decided to create panels which were going to be hold with zip tie on standoff. Servo holders / And camera holder holes are also a little bit in the back.
This STL files are in testing mode for now

• Print LEFT/RIGHT side and Camera Holder with ABS (100% infill for better result)
  • Print Bumpers (x2) with Ninja Semi Flex filament (100% infill for better shock absorption)

title: Weehoo IGo Turbo 2015 Cat's Eye Holder

description.text:
I did not like the way, the cat's eye was mounted to my Weehoo trailer, with only one screw. I could thighten it as hard as I wanted, it started droping down anyhow, threatening to touch the moving wheel. So I decided to design a holder, which keeps the cat's eye upright, even if the screw gets loose.  
Most probably it fits many other models of Weehoo and others, but I can not test it.

title: Radiation / Weather shield for Netatmo outdoor sensor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I ordered a Netatmo weather station and want to have a protective mount for the outdoor sensor as it's not really waterproof and also has to be protected from sun radiation to ensure exact measurements.  
This is a radiation and weather shield to mount the sensor inside.  
Works like a charm! Measurements seem to be accurate, I'll keep an eye on them...

You will need one of the top.stl, one arm.stl and 6 body.stls. The body is intended to be glued together and should have a nice fit on the mounting arm. In the arm, you can insert an M3 nut and screw to hang the Netatmo sensor.  
I printed the top and body parts upside down with support (the body parts with brim) and 100% infill because of the small studs for mounting them together. The arm was printed with 60% infill to make it sturdy enough. The body parts were glued together with UV-curing adhesive (superglue or similar will also work) and the body was put on after the whole thing was mounted to the wall with two 4mm screws.

comments.text: This is pretty neat!  I love your wire twist too -- how did you do that?
comments.author: danesparza

comments.text: Twisting wire is easy. I anchor each wire by tying it to a nail. All of them to the same nail. Then take about... 8 ft of all the wires together, stretch them out & cut off flush. Jam this end into your handy electric drill (With analog trigger). Tighten. You spin the wires and at the same time hold some back pressure on the wire. Too much back pressure and you'll break them. Too little and you will end up with a big knot of wire. So be careful.

author: Gnoff

title: Weehoo IGo Turbo 2015 Seat Post Adapter

description.text:
When I bought the Weehoo trailer bike, I expected the seat post adapter to fit tightly around the seat post, and loosely inside the coupling, so that the adapter does not turn around the seat post, but the coupling around the adapter.   
Of course the real adapter fitted the seat post loosely, and the coupling tightly.  
As I did not want the Weehoo to scratch my seat post, I designed my own adapter, which also fits my very special seat post mount much better.  
I am sure, that it fits other models than just the named one, but I can not test it.  
The .stl-file fits my seat post with 26.8mm diameter. Other seat posts can be dealt with by changing the parameters in the .scad-file. This way you can also make an adapter for a seat post that is not supported by Weehoo.

description.text: This is an attempt at a motormount for a electric longboard written in openscad. It's ment to be welded to the trucks and hold the motor. A pulley is added to the wheel and motor, and a belt sprung between. I haven't printed this or tried it, so no warranties. New update; There is now a 50mm_outrunner_on_randal_RII.scad file that -seems- to be able to be 3D printed!!! Update 2; after ~15km on that print, it broke exactly over the layer between the flat mount, and the upstanding 'tower' holding the hanger. have that glued now with 2 component acrylic based glue, feels more solid than the print :) have ~10km on that again, and still holding .. Update 3; after another ~250km the motor pulley started wearing out from slipping on maximum break. After replacing it, i couldnt get belt alignment accurate enough (apparently) and after another ~50km the belt started to ride into the motormount at got half way through :D I have given up the idea of a printable motormount for now, as other projects are taking lead. But will come back to this later ;) keep posted! More info; https://nurdspace.nl/RobertLongboard

HAVENT TRIED THIS!  
Open this in openscad, tweak the parameters, press F6, appreciate the beauty of parametric design, click Design > Export as STL, done.  
Feed this .stl to your favourite CNC operator to mill out of thick aluminium.  
Feed your truck + the cut aluminium to your favourite welder to join on the right position + orientation.  
Rejoice!

This is a simple mounting bracket for the Microsoft Surface RT.  Just print two of them, screw them into the wall (I used a washer to help distribute the load) and slide in the tablet.  With just two brackets, the tablet is still quite flush to the wall and stable (and you can still take it off!).
I printed on medium using my replicator 2 with supports.  The supports came off nicely and then I just screwed it into the wall with a washer to make sure the piece didn't crack.

This is an outdated (but still playable using Third Edition rules) version of Pocket-Tactics. For the new (and much improved) Fourth Edition sets and pieces, check out this collection. We'll be updating the new edition to include rules for all of the Third Edition units, so if you have printed them (or want to), check in for updates and eventually all of those pieces' rules will be available. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy!

All of the models were printed on a MakerBot Replicator 1 using Makerware's high resolution setting (.1 layer height with 15% infill and 2 shells). I printed many of them split and used modeling glue to stick them together.

comments.text: Thanks for the questions! As written, I can totally understand the confusion. However, when I created them I intended the Fire Walker to be able to summon any unit with the type Elemental (Fire) from reserves into an open adjacent tile. So, for this set, it'd be the 2 Whisps and the Lava Flow. For game balance reasons I only included 3 Elemental (Fire) units in this set, but if you're customizing sets and wanna load up on Elemental (Fire) types, the Fire Walker can summon one per activation until your out of Elemental (Fire) types in reserve.

This is an illustration model of Magdeburg Hemispheres.
"The Magdeburg hemispheres are a pair of large copper hemispheres, with mating rims. They were used to demonstrate the power of atmospheric pressure by Otto von Guericke, in 1656."
This is a model of the original perserved in the Deutsches Museum in Munich. Caution this model is very dangerous for children under 8 years, see intructions this text above are a extract of the Wikipedia:
wiki article: Magdeburg hemispheres News
Version: V1.001 - 5/02/2015 - Corrected printing position on the axis Z of the isolated pieces. Versions V1_001. uploaded. source of data: Wiki, photos, schematics, and other colected data.
Mostly:
Wiki: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magdeburg_hemispheres
Commons: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Magedurger_Halbkugeln_Luftpumpe_Deutsches_Museum.jpg

Magdeburg hemispheres Instructions Warning: This scaled model is not a toy, it is inappropriate for children, the parts are small and fragile, very easy to be broken and can cause fatal injuries if aspirated by children. Please look into
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toy_safety
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home_Safety_Council The model consists of two hemispheres, a seal and a valve.
Make sure the parts are completely at Z = 0, I still did not print any of the parts.
The valve body must be glued separately, the shutter is only fitting.
The rings can be pasted in the hemispheres or carefully separated after printing.
On the upper hemisphere utilize glue and soft plastic spindles on the housing holes along the ring, see: Warning: Never use a metallic spindles on model (see sec. 1.8 on OpenSCAD code),generate the housing holes and utilize glue and soft plastic spindles is very more secure for you and your public. Remember is only a illustration model. Warning: This model is developed for illustration only. Important: is not a working model, not supporting the pressures generated by the vacuum inside the body and may collapse if subjected to this effort. The polymer printed model will not supporting strong efforts, the lack of limits and care in handling can destroy the model. Please read all intructions and keep special attention a Warning information. source of data: Wiki, photos, schematics, and other colected data.
Mostly:
Wiki: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magdeburg_hemispheres
Commons: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Magedurger_Halbkugeln_Luftpumpe_Deutsches_Museum.jpg Important Note: the data were compiled from the best and most accurate way possible for the authors, but in the absence of the original object for measurements and verification of details this data may not reflect the reality.

This is an Arduino powered scale which holds your 3D filament and calculates approximately how much filament you have remaining on your spool in meters. It's fairly accurate (+/- 1 meters when whole spool is on the scale & +/- 5 meters when the printer is pulling on the filament) Closer to the end of the spool, it will get much less accurate as the pull force of the extruder and the spring force of the tighter coiled filament becomes greater than the weight of the spool itself. You should use my remixed spool holder with this scale as it fits perfectly in the tray or you can modify the design to fit one of your own. It can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:804325 Use instructions:
When the scale is booting up, make sure not to have the spool sitting on top. You'll first be asked if you're using 3mm filament, if you are, press and hold the "Tare" button for yes. In the configuration section, you can change the average weight for each diameter filament that you use as well as the average spool weight of your favorite filament for more accuracy. What you'll need to build it:
  • 5 KG Load Cell (http://amzn.to/1GDuutM)
  • HX711 Weighing Sensor AD Module Dual-Channel 24-bit A/D conversion Shielding (http://amzn.to/1JGV7V0)
  • Arduino Uno (http://amzn.to/1FDVNYJ)
  • 20 x 4 LCD screen (http://amzn.to/1DQi4OA)
  • Male to Female Jumper wire (http://amzn.to/1JGVy1w)
  • Assorted 3m and 4m bolts
    • The code for the scale can be found at github (including the required library): https://github.com/smokinpuppy/SpoolScale
    Library: https://github.com/bogde/HX711 Please read the readme file for instructions on how to calibrate the scale correctly. Wiring: (Ar = Arduino, Hx = Hx711, Kn = Knob, Bu = Button, and Sc = Scale Bar)
    Hx711:
    VCC -> 5v (Ar)
    SCK -> A3 (Ar)
    DT -> A2 (Ar)
    GND -> GND (Ar)
    E+ -> RED WIRE (Sc)
    E- -> BLACK WIRE (Sc)
    A- -> WHITE WIRE (Sc)
    A+ -> GREEN WIRE (Sc) LCD J204A:
    VSS+RW -> GND (Ar)
    VDD -> 5v (Ar)
    V0 -> SIN (Kn)
    RS -> D12 (Ar)
    E -> D11 (Ar)
    D4 -> D5 (Ar)
    D5 -> D4 (Ar)
    D6 -> D3 (Ar)
    D7 -> D2 (Ar)
    A -> D9 (Ar)
    K + (Button + Knob) -> GND (Ar) Button:
    VCC -> 5v (Ar)
    SIN -> D7 (Ar)
    GND -> GND (Ar) Knob:
    VCC -> 5v (Ar)
    SIN -> LCD(V0)
    GND -> GND (Ar)

Printer:

Prusa Mendel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%
I printed all the parts using 25% infill (support material needed for the control box and bottom_box) and 0.2 mm layer height.

remixed_from.author: slai98
remixed_from.title: Customized Spool Holder for SainSmart Filament

description.text:
Sainsmart is selling competitively priced filement on Amazon that can be shipped via Amazon prime.  
This filament comes on cheap cardboard spools and the spools are wound to capacity.  The Amazon reivews seem to indicate that the filament is a good value and decent quality, but I have seen some complain that the fact that the spool is wound to capacity can cause problems with the filament falling off the spool and tangling.  
This spool holder is designed to hold these spools.  There is a notich in the spindle to accomodate the plastic plugs that make up the spool hole (which have a flange inside near the center of the spool).  The spool guard helps keep the filament from falling off the spool and tangling.  There is a hook at the end so that the spool holder can be used with other spools that may have a similar inner diameter, but do not require the guard.  Also there is a barb on the machine-side clip to allow the holder to better "snap" into the machine.  
So far, I've printed a few hours on a brand new green spool without tangling or any other problems.

I printed at 15% infill, 1 extra perimeter, 120mm/sec
Curling was a problem, but not terrible. You could use "helper discs" if you were so inclined. After installing the spool holder and spool on the replicator, fit the guard tab into the slot. It is a tight fit and you might need to sand it a bit.

comments.text: What material/settings did you use? I want to make one and have it turn out.
comments.author: candreasen

comments.text:
After a 2 hour 38 minute print of this, I discovered that it is about 1/2" too narrow for the Sainsmart spool that I purchased...maybe they changed their spools. The spool support does not protrude far enough out to expose the hole that the spool guard goes into. The spool guard is also about 1/2" too short to wrap around the outsides of the spool.
The Sainsmart filament prints great. It maintains it's color well and this project had the best finish of anything I have printed so far. I found the Sainsmart filament on Ebay for cheaper than Amazon, so be sure to spend a few minutes to price compare.

description.text: This is a bracket assembly to elevate and hold a dual bulb 2 ft fluorescent light above my 10 gallon aquaponics system. I have a basic metal tube stand below the tank with roughly 3/4 in diameter vertical legs. It consists of 6 printed parts to clamp on the the 2-vertical 5/8 in diameter wood dowels. Using the 3 ft wood dowels it gives me about 1.5 ft of room above the tank to grow plants. The height can be adjusted by sliding the lower clips together and clamping them down. Modify the included STL file if you wish to accommodate different sized dowels or stand diameters.

Print the include parts:
1-Top Clip Light BracketL
1-Top Clip Light BracketR
4-LowerWrapClip2
I printed my parts with 0.2mm layers, 100% infill and minimal support in PLA.
Modified Printrbot Simple, X axis extension, 215C first layer, 212C for the rest and 30 mm/s printing speed. Parts to be purchased:
8- M3 screws (40 mm length)
8-M3 washers
8-M3 hex or locking nuts
6-M5 screws (5 mm length)
2-5/8 in diameter wood dowels (4 ft length) With all the parts printed, thread the M5 screws into the back of each bracket. mount the parts as shown in the pictures with two lower wrap clips on each dowel and 1 top clip light bracket per. Make sure all the clips are straight on the dowel and similarly spaced between the two before tightening the M5 screws into the dowels. Slide the assembly onto the stand legs and use the M3 screws, nuts, washers to tighten on the stand when it is at the desired hanging height. With everything tight and in place, hang your light:)

This is a essentially a add-on remix for jsc's camera mount for the Makergear M2.   
The original mount is awesome as it just clips right onto the frame of the M2 with out any hardware. Unfortunately I used a Logitech C270 and it doesn't have a tripod mount and it is unable to focus too close so I came up with this extension arm to make the field of view adjustable and a new camera mount to work the C270.  
The holes in the pieces are tapped to 4-40 and I use two short screws and washers to secure the camera at the appropriate viewing angle.

title: MakerGear M2 Mount for Raspberry Pi Sleeve Case.

description.text:
I use Octoprint to control one of my Makergear M2 printers but I also like to do a little RetroPi Gaming now and then so I made this quick release mount for my printer so I can quickly remove the Pi when I want to play some Super Mario Kart.  
There are two versions of the mount. Both just use two 4-40 x 1/4" screws to mount it to the printer but one uses heat-set inserts (McMaster Carr part# 93365A120) and the other version can just be drill and tapped for the 4/40 screw. (or force a screw into the mount to thread it.)

If you are going to use Heat Set Inserts.....  thread a screw into the insert so the screw is completely covering all the internal threads of the insert. Hold the screw with needle nose pliers and then just heat the insert with a lighter and press it into the hole in the plastic. Hold it until it cools and then remove the screw.

title: Vibration reducing corner pieces for (feet) rigidbot.

description.text: There are a few other ones on here for the rigidbot but I wanted to tweak them a little.  I liked the one that went into the corner peices.  The mod I did was to create a lip on the bottom to help keep the pads centered.  Additionally because I have the rigidbot big it is heavier so I had to buy the "acoustifeet" ACF3007-25B which were slightly larger than the bottom of the original design but can handle weights up to 48.5 lbs (22kg).  Just because all the weight I would recommend a 30% infill.  Because of the lip on the bottom there is support material underneath but the lip is only 2mm thick so my support material removed cleanly, actually one of the best I have had!

title: Tiny Whoop FX797T and VA1100 Camera Housing Minimalistic

description.text: Updated version weighs only 0.4 grams! VA1100HousingMinimal1.1.stl weighs ~0.4g (PLA, 20% infill) and offers minimal protection. If this one is too fragile for your taste, VA1100Housingv1.1.stl offers a bit more protection at about ~0.5-0.6g. For maximum protection, please see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:807637. Add as many thin strips of double-sided tape as needed to the bottom front to increase the camera angle to suit your kit's setup for FPV racing. Pictured is PFG 110mm CF frame for 7mm motors with accessory plate using Blade Nano QX FPV flight controller, stock Hubsan X4 H107L 7mm motors (have some MMW CL-0720-12 motors, but this thing smokes as is so I'm waiting until the stock motors fail before getting bold enough to try the MMWs), and Parrot MiniDrone Rolling Spider props (stock Hubsan props used in some photos, but these feel quite sluggish compared to the Parrots). As I have a Blade Nano QX FPV that comes with the VA1100 Spektrum Ultra Micro Camera and am variously building and flying other micro quads that I want to use the VA100 on, I needed a housing option to help protect the camera and to place double-sided tape on to make the VA1100 interchangeable on the fly. Designed a bit loose to allow for double-sided tape to prevent jello should you have any. I've not had jello issues, but you may. I use loom rubber bands from Walmart that weigh next to nothing to secure the camera. I made it a bit larger than the VA1100 because I have a blob of 5-minute epoxy on my connections to prevent them from coming loose. You may wish to scale it down by 2-5% to ensure a snug fit if that's your thing. Be aware the power cables from the vtx are quite fragile, so don't scale it down unless you're sure you're comfortable with soldering. Works fine with antenna savers.

comments.text: Hi there.  That is the 110mm Phoenix Flight Gear CF Micro-H frame for 7mm motors with optional accessory plate.

A simple vase to test on your Dual extruders!

This is a linear delta 3D printer based on Johann's Rostock which has been enlarged to acomodate roughly double the print volume. All of the 3D printed & laser cut parts have been made thanks to the Artilect Fablab Toulouse. This is still work in progress so below you will find a blog like story of the build & set-up:

  • 30/08/2013 Discovered that one of the Idler_end started to develop cracks, therefore the design of the idler_end was updated to be stronger and as well for a better installation of the end stops.
    Updated Idler End design (V1.2) is there: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:143186

  • 27/08/2013 Found an interesting improvement by Antonio Bencini which adapted magnetic bearings to the enlarged Rostock, this is really cool!

    • Platform: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:139730
    • Carriage: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:139264

  • 23/08/2013 Back from holidays...

    • Following Zoltan's comment I realized that I had forgotten to put the platform STL, this is corrected now. Anyway it is unchanged from the Original Rostock one.

  • 09/07/2013 Presentation of the Enlarged rostock development (in French, sorry for the English speakers) http://prezi.com/slg0ddtggc2_/?utm_campaign=share&utm_medium=copy

  • 15/06/2013 Refined calibration

    • Refined the calibration of the extruder folowing the process proposed by:

      • Triffid Hunter: http://reprap.org/wiki/Triffid_Hunter%27s_Calibration_Guide
      • Tantillus: http://www.tantillus.org/Tutorials.html
    • Performed retraction calibratio, After fiddeling with various retraction values & extra lengt values I did not notice much improvments or even much difference until I stumbled on this discussion http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?262,156806,157207 and this Blog: http://systematictechnology.net/?tag=calibration where I understood that my max feedrate should be around 10mm/s and before it was set to 100 or 200mm/s which was way to high but it did not strike me as Repetier you set filament speed around 100 but mm/min & not mm/s.

  • 09/06/2013 Some Updates

    • Demonstrated the printer at the Artilect Fablab Toulouse on the 03/06 (Picture of it being re assembled there). http://artilect.fr/
    • Added cable tentioner to allow speed increase without shacking
    • Insulated the hotend to be able to perform efficient cooling without affecting hotend temperature http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:101104
    • Chased play in the wade extruder drive.

  • 25/05/2013 First Perfect Print !

    • As on small part there were thermal issues I decided to test larger prints.
    • I went for the 6 sided Vase from
      MaakMijnIdee http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18672
    • Printed with blue PLA 0.2mm layer thickness, 207degC for first layer & 197degC for the others, speed 40% of prusa std settings (5hour print time)
    • The result excellent :) It will be time to accelerate...

  • 22/05/2013 Biger & More precise but stil thermal issues

    • Slightly tightened the belts to improve acuracy
    • Went for the large Lucy the cat (in blue) with no ventilation & still at low velocity
    • Low parts where excellent with a good prescision of the layers
    • One can notice a problem around the head of the cat which give it a frog attitude. This was due to excessive softening of the material & partial colapse.

  • 21/05/2013 Post mortem & Back to life

    • Went to see the E-Motion Tech people with my dead J-Head and after post mortem analysis they figured out that the termistor reading was not correct it should be around 90k Ohms and was 120k. They where very kind & helped me to restore the head.
    • Now back to life calibrating properly the thermistor.

  • 20/05/2013 The J-Head lost it's head!

    • Trying to print another lucy the cat after tightening the belt to get a bit more prescision, Extrusion was not going well again. I tried to do a manual extrude, temperature was set @ 210degC, there it felt strange the extruder stepper's seemed to force significantely jumping some steps but the PLA was only going out lazily.
    • Sudently I the head started to move & poped out before I could stop the mains power.

  • 19/05/2013 Fighting with the Cat

    • Today I tried to print something beter than a cube but still relatively small & simple So I went for Lucy the cat http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24255 which is small & rather low difficulty.
    • Yesturday wen printing the cube I realised that it required cooling so I installed a PC fan (which was the cause of follow up difficulties)
    • As you can see on the second row of the picture there has been several failures before getting something that looks like the STL. To make a long story short temperature is measured on the top part of the Brass part of the J-Head hotend, which hsa been a bit isolated with layers of kapton tape. however the tip of the hotend is not insulated and would get some degrees colder suficiently to reach very hygh viscosity of the PLA dramatically reducing the flow.
      and at the same time cloging the teeth of the filament pushing axis.
    • Increasing temperature by 10degC & cleaning the extruder was the solution.
    • Looking at the last Lucy printed it is not yet perfect the layers are not well alligned, so my next task will be to fight the play to ensure everything is alligned.
    • In addition I need to work on the extruder as for the moment the Wade's extruder sit on top of the platform limiting the movment of the printers and I have not yet ordered the tube to make the bowden extruder which was initially planned. As I start to realise that booth systems have different advantage & weekness. I guess the solution could be to devise an interchangable system able to do booth.

  • 18/05/2013 Geting a bit better...

    • Just made two more print reducing temperature & extruder feed and now it start to look as a very small cube 10mmx10mm. (see the picture)

  • 17/05/13 First Print!!!

    • After fighting without sucess to have Repetier working I guess I will need to get an atmega1284 to replace the 644 that came with the Gen7 but which lacks memory for Delta printers.
    • I finnaly manage to get a 10uH self to replace the 100uH original one and got rid of the brown outs
    • Over the week I had to transport the printer a few hundred kilometers by car and apparently it did notlike it as play started to appear on some components and notably the joints.
    • Very late tonight I finally manage to attempt a first print: a 10mm cube, there was to much plastic feed and the hot end was too hot, so the result is not great see the picture and the video http://youtu.be/8jBBFH91Mn0.
    • Still some work to do to have high quality prints. Any way I'm very happy to be finnaly able to have a first print.

  • 12/05/13 A bit frustrating

    • I finnally managed to have the repeter firmware heating the hot end (the temperature measurement will need calibration)
    • For some strange reason it needs to be on the bed sensor plug & not the extruder, I guess I'l need to go & see in the Pin layout of the firmware.
    • But with repetier I do not manage to get the axis moving !
    • So I have the axis moving on the Marlin & extruder heating on Repetier...

  • 11/05/13 Trying to get it hot

    • Assambled the hot end
    • Assambled the extruder (Wade) initial plan was tu use it deported (Bowden) with a Teflon tube to link it to the hot end but I do not yer have the tube so it will be mounted directly on the platform. limiting speed & amplitude in the mean time.
    • With a friend we assembled the hot end to the extruder and then tryed it on the board. We were quite disapointed to see that there was still a 0degC temperature reading. I just realosed now that on the 06/05 the quick fix that I used to stop the broun out problem disables the temperatures. and I could not yet purchace the termistance to definately correct the brownout problem.
    • Therfore I tryed the Repetier-firmware with the lower memory settings & it seems to work. (it still needs to be configured properly for the rest.
    • Tryed again the heater with the Repetier-Firmware and there it was displaying -55degC which felt strange as earlier we tested the thermistor resistance & it was around 114k Ohms.

  • 10/05/13 Plenty of problems & some solutions:

    • After all the problem described bellow it finaly made some first decent drawings see the video: http://youtu.be/04nmR4zaZQw
    • Marlin Configuration Files & Test STL used for the drawings added to the downloadable files.
    • Found the solution for the homming problems from yesturday Had to reduce Max speed in the firmware.
    • Still one of the axis was not moving properly. At first I thought it was losing steps so I tried to increase the Driver's Current without sucess, I even switched the Drivers without results, to finnaly find that it was the pulley that was not tight enough.
    • Once that was solved I went back to drawing experiments and for some reason the drawings were to small & the overal movements where shorter than expected, after verifying all the set-up of the firmware was more or less correct found one error on the DELTA_CARRIAGE_OFFSET which was 22 on the original rostock & now is 28.0mm but this did not solve the main problem. Therfore I started to measure the belt pitch which was 2.5mm as expected and I went to count the numbers of teeth and there I understood where the problem was comming from: The pulley which I thought was an 18teeth one was in fact a 16teeth one. Once this corrected in the firmware It gave much better results.
    • Still some issues of steps lost from time to time
    • Glonally it looks rather sensitive to the speed the 400 steps per revolution & the 16 teeth T2.5 pulley means that it is hitting the maximum steps/s limits of the arduino
    • On top of that there is some issues of repetability of the starting height due to the endstops set-up which is not yet perfect
    • With all this I did not get a chance to try again the Repeter Firmware.

  • 09/05/13

    • Installation of end-stops
    • Start of calibration
    • It made it's first drawings (It is not great for the time being)
    • Some issues with homming: when moves comands are sent it moves correctely but when homming the steppers vibrates and nothing moves. I assume it is a error in my ste-up of the firmware, or too low current in the stepers drivers TBC.
    • Had some feedback on the issue with Repetier http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?267,206320 which should come from an excess usage of memory so I will try to lower the memory useage as advised and I will let you know.

  • 07/05/13 Platform fitted & moving

    • Diagonal rods Cut from The carbon Arrows & glued to the Jaws
    • Got some extra MDF to rigidify the structure at some later point
    • Fitted Diagolal rods & Platform to the Printer
    • Tried some movements: it is not perfectely flat yet nor rapid but it is going the right way. Here is a video of some of the first moves http://youtu.be/qAyjTx0MV_U
    • The Z stepper seems a bit week I will need to adjust the power on the driver.

  • 06/05/13 IT MOVES!!!

    • Did not work on the structure today
    • Temporarly gave-up on Repieter Firmware and moved to the modified Marlin by Johann
    • Got Brown out issue on Marlin as described in the following thread https://github.com/ErikZalm/Marlin/issues/174 Got to change L1 on the Gen7 V1.4.1 as explained on the last post. I used the temporary fix from the first post as I do not require heating.
    • Had to invert the Pinning of the steppers for them to turn on the correct direction
    • For some strange reason the M80 comand needs to be entered manually
    • Now all the three axis moves corectly on delta mode!

  • 05/05/13 Now it looks like something

    • Installed The belts & Steppers on each axis
    • Assembled the Three Axes with the frame
    • Still fighting with Repetier Firmware to make it work in delta mode

  • 04/05/13 Start of the assembly

    • The three columns of the printer are now complete
    • All motors & endstops are properly wired & tested on cartesian mode
    • Configured & uploaded the delta mode of Repetier but for some reason the stepers do not move in delta mode. Still need to beter understand config...
  • 03/05/13 Back to the printer after a forced pause.
    Today I have been playing with the Gen7 & the stepers:
    • Ran the Test set-up with sucess
    • Installed the repetier firmware 0.82.2 & tested with sucess the cartesian mode steppers turning ok.
    • Started to set-up the delta mode of the repetier firmware but haven't had the time to test it today.
    • Enlarged version of Johann's Rostock adapted with the folowing features:
  • 400x400x500mm expected build area
  • 0.08mm theoretical vertical presision (400step/rev + 16 teeth T2.5 Pulley)
  • Carriages with self tensioning & play elimination
    • It is just the begining... Almost everything is available now it is time to start building. To be Continued

BOM:
Builded Parts:
  • Motor_End x 3 -> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:71687
  • Idler_End V1.2 x 3 -> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:143186
  • Carriage V1.2 x3 -> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:80425
  • Bed x 2 -> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74119
  • Platform x1, Jaws x 12, Joint x 12 -> from the original Rostock http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17175
  • Extruder still to be defined
    • Purchased parts:
  • Round Shaft 12mmx1000mm Z-12-1000A x 6 -> 88.12Eur Obtained From HPC Europe: http://shop.hpceurope.com/an/produit.asp?prid=1321&produit=Shaft+for+linear+guidance&famille=Linear%20motion&catalogue=Linear%20guidance%20parts
  • Linear Bearings 12mm KB-12-WW x 6 -> 67.09Eur Obtained from HPC Europe: http://shop.hpceurope.com/an/produit.asp?prid=2631&produit=Linear+bearing&famille=Linear%20motion&catalogue=Linear%20guidance%20parts
  • Gen 7 V1.4.1 board x 1-> 145Eur Obtained from eMotion Tech : http://www.reprap-france.com/12-electronique
    Nema17 400 step/turn x4 -> 88.30Eur Obtained from Selectronics: http://www.selectronic.fr/moteur-pas-a-pas-modele-pap-2.html
  • Belt 2m T2.5 x3 & Pulley 18 tooth x3 in fact got 16tooth ones -> 75.06Eur + 18.63Eur Obtained from eMotion Tech : http://www.reprap-france.com/14-courroies
  • HotEnd Jhead MK5B x1 -> Obtained from eMotion Tech : http://www.reprap-france.com/extrudeur-hot-end/57-t%C3%AAte-chauffante-j-head-mk5b-pr%C3%A9-assembl%C3%A9e-3mm.html
  • Diagonal rod made from 5mm x 790mm carbon Arrow (GEOLOGIC110) -> 15Eur Obtained from Decathlon
    Improvments could be made there as I've been seeking rapid availability and could have optimised the cost better.

comments.author: azent

comments.text:
• 10mm rods: well from 12 to 10mm the difference is not huge, but yes it would make it a bit more wobbly, in fact when I started to accelerate the prints I had to add crossed stiffening cables with tensioners to stiffen the printer
  • For the control board I use the Gen7 V1.4.1 (now you can get V1.5 which would be better and allow to avoid the self issue) this is a full Arduino compatible bord, therefore no additional Arduino bord is required.
    • I went for the Gen7 because it is the only board running at 20Mhz (all the others are running at 16Mhz)
    • You would need to make sure it comes equipped with an Atmega 1284 as it has much more memory
    • Delta printers require more cpu & memory.
  • The best resolution that works well with the printer up to now is 0.1mm, I have tried 0.05m but failed to see a difference.
  • I left you a message with my email address.

remixed_from.title: Lulzbot TAZ 5 / 4 Low Friction Spool Holder Mount

description.text: Inspired by others I have been trying to find a better way to feed the filament to my TAZ 4. To hold the bearings and the spool I opted for the design from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:235925 which was also suggested by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:773863 However, I had some trouble with that mount when feeding brittle filaments - the extra distance from the filament tube caused more frequent breaks. So I used OnShape to design a more compact mount. The OnShape design is public at https://cad.onshape.com/documents/72cefc6fb8cf4e0eaa77627b/w/b097f666a62647f2b67e9ccf/e/e11dd2c102c64ad3b50fb66a Files updated

Printed on my Lulzbot TAZ 4 in PolyMax by PolyMakr at .2mm layers, 3 shells, 25% infill. Sliced with Simplify3D  
The photos are of the first version and you can see there is a little splitting near the screw holes. The STL files and the OnShape CAD has been updated to add 3mm to the securing arms.  
You'll need 2 608zz bearings, a length of m8 threaded rod, 4 m8 nuts and 2 m8 flat washers. I used 30mm self tapping flat head screws perhaps #6 gauge?

comments.text: Nice re-mix.  Great job making the whole thing more compact!

title: Cobra Radar Detector Mount Suction Cup Adapter

description.text:
This is for a very specific issue I had.  I have a Cobra SPX 7800BT radar detector and one of the suction cups for its window holder was damaged.  I found replacements at Hobby Lobby with a great diameter, but couldn't be held by the bracket, so I created this adapter/shim to provide the extra width and thickness to hold the suctions cups with the mount.   
I don't know if anyone else will need such a thing, but it might help as a starting point for others.

The black one shown is PLA, but I live in the southeast, so ABS is a minimum requirement and is what I printed the brown version.  
Place the first suction cup in the radar detector mount and insert the shim to hold it in place.  Place the second suction cup in the mount and then rotate the shim around to the second suction cup.  It will take a little maneuvering to snap in place.  
This provides the thickness to hold the mount to the windshield as well as holding the suctions cups outward within the smaller openings of the mount.

comments.text:
Cool.
You can find more suction cups on https://www.isuctioncups.com
comments.author: isuctioncups

author: SpectreGadget

description.text: This is a simple adapter to mount an iPhone to a microscope. The eyepiece clamp is optimized for a 28mm lens but might fit larger eyepieces. I omitted additional clamps for now to simplify the print and to allow adjustment of the iPhone so the image comes in clearly as it's tricky to get everything to line up correctly. Since the adapter has a clamp it's possible to move the adapter and phone up or down on the eyepiece to get the correct focal distance. I clamp the iPhone to the adapter with a rubber band which seems to hold it fairly securely but still allows room to adjust it. This design was inspired by FlorentBonnefoi's nice design at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:178047.

This was designed in Rhino 5 and printed in natural HIPS on a LulzBot Mini using Cura. Extruder temperature was set to 240C and bed temperature set to 60C.Used the Normal quality print setting in Cura. You will probably want to print with support for the clamp.
